subject: Re: [junit] Experience with jdk1.4 assert keyword
msgSnippet: ... It s not bad in itself - it s bad when I use it instead of proper design and testing to catch things that might go wrong at runtime. When I started using
messageBody:
> Why is something like
> assert foo != null : "Foo null";
> a bad thing?

It's not bad in itself - it's bad when I use it instead of proper design and
testing to catch things that "might go wrong" at runtime. When I started
using asserts, I tended to use them everywhere. They (1) polluted my code,
and (2) where often a way to mask my laziness when designing my code and
tests. In other words: I try not to use assertions to check that my code is
not bugged. That's the tests' job. I still use asserts to check internal
consistency when writing complicated algorithms, but I usually look forward
to removing them when I have a good test suite running against that code.

In many cases, unproper use of a method is the responsibility of the client.
If a public method receives a null object, that's probably an error on the
side of the caller. My method won't have to deal with that - I'll just let
out a NullPointerException.
